My time at USV was horrible.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good relationships with colleagues and students.
cons:
COVID-related cost cuts have devastated the school at all levels and now the majority of the people responsible for the positive elements in the school are no longer there, like most of the professors who trained the top alumni from the college. 

In the last 6-12 months the best administrators who had big connections and amazing resumes were laid off, or they abandoned ship. Huge proportion of the best FT and PT faculty got laid off due to cost cutting, retired, or left for different jobs. Significant experienced staff members have left or were let go.

COVID is surely the core cause, but those people are not coming back and the institution is much worse off if you are a student or work there.

review_title: Master's Degree and Professional Experience hiring at $28/hr
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Jose, CA
pros: Fun students and free snacks.
cons:
70 hrs per class/semester on paper, but no extra compensation for grading and class preparation.  If you have never taught before, understand that those things take the same number of hours as teaching does (or more!)

At $4000/class/semester this means you are making $28/hr at best, probably less.

There are never full-time positions.  Those who are full-time say the pay is bad and benefits are bare bones.  Give up on that dream immediately if you think that will ever happen.

Anyone skilled and employable in tech or entertainment in The Bay makes twice that with only a Bachelor's.  If a student ever wonders about their teacher quality --- that's why!

This job is for the charitable/codependents and the temporarily unemployed only.  Teach somewhere else if you want to "give back"/try to pay back your own student loans.

review_title: Faculty in For-profit educational institute: Pros and Cons
job_title: Faculty, FT in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
The students are great: Artistic, creative. Some get for the first time appreciation for doing art work!
As a for profit, you also get less capable students (who are willing to pay the money and try). But for those students who stick around, it is a pleasure to work with.
cons: Private for profit is a real problem. Especially when the owner is remote, and not involved in the school. The impression you get is that he is in it only for the money. The faculty is there for the  students and as a mission, but decisions are made without their control.
